STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 13, 2022
Melissa VanLuven
2218 Shunk Road
Sault Ste Marie, MI 49783
RE: License #: CN170201399
Sault Tribe Binogii - Placement
2218 Shunk Road
Sault Ste Marie, MI 49783
Dear Ms. VanLuven:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 8, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 383-5531
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will al MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables: Updated Case Plan (USP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
One of 6 foster care files contained a case management FTM which occurred more
than 30 days prior to the case plan due date.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts - Timely Entry of Contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in MISACWIS within five business
days of the contact. This includes attempted and missed
face-to-face contacts. • Any face-to-face contact with
children, parents, or caregivers made by any of the
following: Foster care caseworker or supervisor. CPS
caseworker or supervisor. Adoption caseworker or
supervisor.
Five of 6 foster care files reviewed contained face to face contacts that were entered
more than 5 working days from the date of the contact.
Repeat Violation Established.
August 5, 2021, Interim, CAP Approved August 26, 2021.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:  Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, checking it for accuracy, identifying areas
needing follow-up, and recording the outcome data.  The
4

caseworker must enter the FTM information (DHS-1105) in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business
days of the FTM.
One of 6 files reviewed did not contain an uploaded DHS-1105 for an FTM
conducted on May 18, 2022. The Chief Administrator submitted a hard copy of the
DHS-1105 indicating the FTM had been completed however it was not uploaded into
the MISACWIS system.
FOM 722-06H Case Contact – Quality Visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster
care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker: • Can meet with each child individually,
without the presence of other individuals, to give the child
an opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement. • Views the child's bedroom and
sleeping arrangements. • Verifies safe sleep environments
and practices for infants under 12 months. • Assesses each
child’s educational, medical, dental, mental health and
other needs and takes appropriate action or offers services
in response to the identified needs of each child. • Shows
interest in the child to build and establish rapport. • Shares
and explains the case plan, including the plan for parenting
time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the child's
permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate way
while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
Two of 6 foster care files reviewed lacked documentation of quality visits. One file
documented two visits where a private meeting with the child was not documented.
Discussion of medical and school needs as well as viewing the child’s bedroom was
also not conducted. The second file lacked documentation during two visits that the
infant’s sleeping arrangement was viewed. Medical needs were also not
documented.
FOM 722-08E Case Closing
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change, (3 days).
5

Two of 2 closed foster care files reviewed did not contain a DHS-69 closing action
summary. The Chief Administrator submitted hard copies of the DHS-69 for each file
indicating the action summary’s were completed however they were not uploaded
into the MISACWIS system.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas.
 It was recommended that the agency clearly document the date an orientation
for a prospective adoptive family was conducted as well as the date the family
was provided an application. This information could be noted in the social
work contacts or on an internal form/checklist.
 It was recommended that the agency clearly document the date when an
adoption worker was assigned to the case after the referral for adoption.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan, approved August 26, 2021, was submitted in response to
the Interim Inspection completed on August 5, 2021. There was one repeat violation
established during the current Renewal Inspection regarding the timely entering of
face to face contacts into the MISACWIS system. The agency continues to
successfully address and correct rule and policy violations established during the
previous annual inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and it was thorough in addressing violations and CAP
successes during the licensing period. The CA indicated staff turnover and the
pandemic has presented challenges for the agency. The CA also indicated that the
CTWI training falls short of preparing workers for the challenges of the foster care
worker position. The CA indicated that the training online has it’s benefits and
6

drawbacks. The CA also indicated that the MISACWIS system is cumbersome for
workers and staff and it is hoped that the new system will be more user friendly.
Interviews:
Interviews were conducted with six staff. Three of the staff interviewed were recently
employed and had completed CTWI training and had caseloads. Each of the three
staff indicated that they receive competent and supportive supervision from their
supervisor as well as other administrative staff. They also reported that they feel
they are part of a team that is supportive. Administrative staff interviewed spoke of
the challenges they meet with staff turnover, the effects of the pandemic, and
frequent system and policy changes. Administrative staff were positive regarding the
staff and the team at the agency.
Field Analyst Findings:
The Field Analyst identified and generated two safety alerts during her visits to the
foster/relative homes. A safety alert dated April 1, 2022, was corrected by the
agency on the same date. The safety concern was a missing doorknob on a child’s
bedroom door.
A second safety alert generated on April 21, 2022, identified the home missing
smoke alarms, a carbon monoxide detector, and a gun in a closet which was not
locked. The safety alert was resolved on May 5, 2022. The agency had also initiated
a special investigation, #2022C0630800, to address the deficiencies in the home.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
June 9, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 13, 2022
